SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: „2nd Circuit Rules Phone Dragnet Exceeds Section 215
Here’s the opinion. This will be a working thread.
(27) LOL! I love this line, which was surely written for Sam Alito.
„Appellants here need not speculate that the government has collected, or may in the future collect, their call records.““
Richard Burr’s IP Dragnet Disappears into the Memory Hole
As I noted yesterday, Richard Burr gave a planned colloquy on the Senate floor yesterday in which he said bulk collection included IP addresses.

There is no sign of an end to the erosion of Constitutional liberties that began under George W. Bush after the 9/11 attacks and continues under Barack Obama, a group of seven national security whistleblowers said Monday.

“The government chose in great secrecy to unchain itself,” said Thomas Drake, who was working at the National Security Agency in 2001 and said he saw lawlessness spread under the name of “exigent conditions” during the Bush presidency.

Then, as part of Obama’s war on whistleblowers <a href="http://niemanreports.org/articles/the-big-chill/" target="_blank">war on whistleblowers</a> , prosecutors charged Drake under the Espionage Act – a law intended to brutally punish spies – for talking to a reporter. After a four-year long ordeal that the federal judge in his case called “unconscionable,” all 10 felony charges against Drake were dropped in return for his guilty plea to a single misdemeanor.

Now, Drake said, he is throwing his weight behind H.R. 1466 <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/1466/all-info" target="_blank">H.R. 1466</a> , the Surveillance State Repeal Act.

The bill would completely repeal the 2001 PATRIOT Act (which the NSA cites as the legal basis for its bulk phone metadata collection), repeal the FISA Amendments Act (which ostensibly legitimizes Internet spying) and otherwise protect people’s privacy.“
„Chelsea Manning writes bill to protect journalism and curb Espionage Act
The US soldier imprisoned for leaking state secrets in 2010 seeks to reform laws used to prosecute journalists and whistleblowers in the name of national security+“
Most people realize that emails and other digital communications they once considered private can now become part of their permanent record.
But even as they increasingly use apps that understand what they say, most people don’t realize that the words they speak are not so private anymore, either.

Top-secret documents from the archive of former NSA contractor Edward Snowden show the National Security Agency can now automatically recognize the content within phone calls by creating rough transcripts and phonetic representations that can be easily searched and stored.

The documents show NSA analysts celebrating the development of what they called “Google for Voice” nearly a decade ago <a href="https://firstlook.org/theintercept/document/2015/05/05/media-mining-future-now/" target="_blank">nearly a decade ago</a> .
„America's Willing Helper: Intelligence Scandal Puts Merkel in Tight Place

Germany's latest spying scandal has created the biggest crisis yet for the country's foreign intelligence agency. The German government appears to have been aware of widespread US spying, possibly including economic espionage, against European targets and yet it did nothing to stop it.“
"Chelsea Manning writes bill to protect journalism and curb Espionage Act"
"The US soldier imprisoned for leaking state secrets in 2010 seeks to reform laws used to prosecute journalists and whistleblowers in the name of national security“

<img src="http://2.static.img-dpreview.com/files/w/TS560x560?url=http%3A%2F%2Fthebruns.ca%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2FCoverIdea-624x688.jpg&amp;signature=8B639oiqyvpkJfUnyXQDwjhBE0s%3D" data-dpr-src-type="w" data-dpr-url="http://thebruns.ca/wp-content/uploads/CoverIdea-624x688.jpg" data-dpr-original-width="624" data-dpr-original-height="688" class="forumImage" data-dpr-large-image-url="http://1.static.img-dpreview.com/files/w/TS940x940?url=http%3A%2F%2Fthebruns.ca%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2FCoverIdea-624x688.jpg&amp;signature=59y8Gx9K%2FSFQSk1j8%2Fe8C8KVci8%3D" data-dpr-xlarge-image-url="http://3.static.img-dpreview.com/files/w/TS1600x1600?url=http%3A%2F%2Fthebruns.ca%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2FCoverIdea-624x688.jpg&amp;signature=GmSXAxxEKOjskh9xPYe8uGkzk9Q%3D" data-dpr-full-image-url="http://1.static.img-dpreview.com/files/w/E?url=http%3A%2F%2Fthebruns.ca%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2FCoverIdea-624x688.jpg&amp;signature=PrE1qRnoCkkGpMSAluizS7aIkGQ%3D" data-dpr-clickthrough-url="http://thebruns.ca/wp-content/uploads/CoverIdea-624x688.jpg" width="508" height="560" data-dpr-small-image-width="508" data-dpr-small-image-height="560" data-dpr-large-image-width="624" data-dpr-large-image-height="688" data-dpr-xlarge-image-width="624" data-dpr-xlarge-image-height="688" data-dpr-full-image-width="624" data-dpr-full-image-height="688">

I find it hard to believe that federal courts so stubbornly refuse to require Congress to enumerate the authority that grants them the ability to pass legislation that circumvents and contradicts provisions contained within the U.S. Constitution.

The right to privacy and the security of one's property, possessions, and papers; the requirement for probable cause and obtaining a warrant to arrest someone are not things that can be legislated away by simple acts of Congress. They require a national referendum that amends the Constitution.

Instead we've got kidnapping, unjustified imprisonment, secret courts using secret evidence, assassinations, undeclared "wars," and national security agencies that ignore the laws that make it a crime to lie to federal officials and Congress. It's upside down, and few people are willing to speak out against it.

Eric Snowden was brave enough to do something about it. republicans and democrats alike refuse to support him and his cause. What is his cause? The defense of the U.S. Constitution which is the document that secures our freedom and liberty. The same document these politicians in Congress, and the politician in the White House have sworn to defend. Then we have the right wing pundits who blindly support the positions taken by the national security state and the bankers and corporations it is sworn to defend.
„2nd Circuit Rules Phone Dragnet Exceeds Section 215

„America's Willing Helper: Intelligence Scandal Puts Merkel in Tight Place

Germany's latest spying scandal has created the biggest crisis yet for the country's foreign intelligence agency. The German government appears to have been aware of widespread US spying, possibly including economic espionage, against European targets and yet it did nothing to stop it.“
We already require, sometimes A DOZEN FBI agents to track ONE suspected terrorist. Terror suspects not unlike the ones who were shot and killed in Texas recently.

By taking many of the monitoring / surveillance tools off of the table, the cost of tracking such suspects or even initially flagging them in the first place will go up EXPONENTIALLY. The result of neutering our intelligence agencies would potentially have a HUGE proportion of suspected terrorists go undetected and untracked. We are now bound and screwed.

By taking many of the monitoring / surveillance tools off of the table, the cost of tracking such suspects or even initially flagging them in the first place will go up EXPONENTIALLY. The result of neutering our intelligence agencies would potentially have a HUGE proportion of suspected terrorists go undetected and untracked. We are now bound and screwed.
And how is the national security state monitoring you phone calls, and mine, and your internet activity, and mine, in violation of the Constitution, protecting you and I from terrorist attack?

Federal officials take an oath to defend the Constitution; they take no oath to keep the American People safe from harm. How does violating the oath one takes upon entering public office protect and defend the Constitution?
As a soldier I took no oath to defend you or your children or American interests. I agreed to protect and defend the Constitution, and obey the lawful orders of my superiors.

FYI, according to official police statements issued following the incident, the suspects were taken out of action thanks to an insurance agent who required the organizers of the event to hire additional security, since that event was created to assuage the redneck bigotry designed to deliberately insult the religious superstitions and bigotry of an opposing point of view.
To the best of my knowledge, the NSA, CIA, FBI, and Homeland Security played no part in this at all. It was all the doing of local law enforcement.
We already require, sometimes A DOZEN FBI agents to track ONE suspected terrorist. Terror suspects not unlike the ones who were shot and killed in Texas recently.

By taking many of the monitoring / surveillance tools off of the table, the cost of tracking such suspects or even initially flagging them in the first place will go up EXPONENTIALLY. The result of neutering our intelligence agencies would potentially have a HUGE proportion of suspected terrorists go undetected and untracked. We are now bound and screwed.
How do you feel about your vaunted Constitution now?

Some can make the argument that portions of It should be updated to reflect modern times. Clearly, the terrorists and ill doers could care less about our constitution. They are using it against us and succeeding. Who knew.

„Chelsea Manning writes bill to protect journalism and curb Espionage Act
The US soldier imprisoned for leaking state secrets in 2010 seeks to reform laws used to prosecute journalists and whistleblowers in the name of national security+“
Most people realize that emails and other digital communications they once considered private can now become part of their permanent record.
But even as they increasingly use apps that understand what they say, most people don’t realize that the words they speak are not so private anymore, either.

Top-secret documents from the archive of former NSA contractor Edward Snowden show the National Security Agency can now automatically recognize the content within phone calls by creating rough transcripts and phonetic representations that can be easily searched and stored.

Long before the Internet I learned that anything I write (especially in business) or do could end up being used in evidence for or against me. I had security clearance for many years starting in 1963 because I was a radar designer for airplanes for over nine years. I was a prime candidate for blackmail as well. There was no way I would have betrayed my country (Canada) or my previous one (Finland). Canada did not even have its own Constitution then. Our personal freedom was guaranteed by the British North America Act.

The documents show NSA analysts celebrating the development of what they called “Google for Voice” nearly a decade ago <a href="https://firstlook.org/theintercept/document/2015/05/05/media-mining-future-now/" target="_blank">nearly a decade ago</a> .
„America's Willing Helper: Intelligence Scandal Puts Merkel in Tight Place

Germany's latest spying scandal has created the biggest crisis yet for the country's foreign intelligence agency. The German government appears to have been aware of widespread US spying, possibly including economic espionage, against European targets and yet it did nothing to stop it.“
When you thank Snowden are you doing it just on your own behalf, Germany's behalf, America's behalf, or all of humanity's behalf?

You have a total right to your own beliefs, of course now that you live in a united Germany. You did not when you lived in East Germany and marched against the government there. Now you persistently rail against the US and try to shove your beliefs down some people's throats, like mine for example. You essentially called me, a <b>Canadian<b>, a dog on G.W. Bush's leash. Some people may think I'm an SOB but have not said so to my face. You would not dare either.

FYI, I did not think that the second Iraq war was a good idea at all. Canada did not support it. One of my Arab friends said that Iraq could never become a stable democracy because it was and is composed of three peoples who don't like each other. Even Joe Biden said that once.
Now what about Russia. I might have missed it, but what are your thoughts about Russia and Ukraine?
„2nd Circuit Rules Phone Dragnet Exceeds Section 215

Long before the Internet I learned that anything I write (especially in business) or do could end up being used in evidence for or against me. I had security clearance for many years starting in 1963 because I was a radar designer for airplanes for over nine years. I was a prime candidate for blackmail as well. There was no way I would have betrayed my country (Canada) or my previous one (Finland). Canada did not even have its own Constitution then. Our personal freedom was guaranteed by the British North America Act.
When you thank Snowden are you doing it just on your own behalf, Germany's behalf, America's behalf, or all of humanity's behalf?

You have a total right to your own beliefs, of course now that you live in a united Germany. You did not when you lived in East Germany and marched against the government there. Now you persistently rail against the US and try to shove your beliefs down some people's throats, like mine for example. You essentially called me, a <b>Canadian<b>, a dog on G.W. Bush's leash. Some people may think I'm an SOB but have not said so to my face. You would not dare either.

FYI, I did not think that the second Iraq war was a good idea at all. Canada did not support it. One of my Arab friends said that Iraq could never become a stable democracy because it was and is composed of three peoples who don't like each other. Even Joe Biden said that once.
Now what about Russia. I might have missed it, but what are your thoughts about Russia and Ukraine?

Well, a good place to start is where you left off. So, lets talk about Russia. Or more specifically, Stalin's Russia. Or the previous example, East Germany. Ohhh, this is Canada. This is America. Abuses of power could never happen here. What the big deal about Snowden's revelations was the fact that, until his actions, NOBODY knew this was going on at all. You say, 'oh, I worked for an agency and already knew I was being watched.' But did you know to what degree and how much information was on file on you? What if you had a lot to lose? A family, kids about to enroll in college, a lifesaving medical procedure. A lot to lose. You get called in to the NSA and 'blackmailed' into co-oporating with whoever wants someone gone from the power structure. Listen more closely to what is already going on with forced confessions and people being sent to prison with false evidence. A million little ways you can be forced into subverting the basics of a democratic society. What if it gets worse? Journalists deciding not to publish important stories. I am fairly sure we are already behind the curve. It is only people who are brave enough to take a snowballs chance they won't be in solitary for life for nothing to show for it that the information we now know is being talked about. (27) LOL! I love this line, which was surely written for Sam Alito.
„Appellants here need not speculate that the government has collected, or may in the future collect, their call records.““
Richard Burr’s IP Dragnet Disappears into the Memory Hole
As I noted yesterday, Richard Burr gave a planned colloquy on the Senate floor yesterday in which he said bulk collection included IP addresses.

There is no sign of an end to the erosion of Constitutional liberties that began under George W. Bush after the 9/11 attacks and continues under Barack Obama, a group of seven national security whistleblowers said Monday.

“The government chose in great secrecy to unchain itself,” said Thomas Drake, who was working at the National Security Agency in 2001 and said he saw lawlessness spread under the name of “exigent conditions” during the Bush presidency.

Then, as part of Obama’s war on whistleblowers <a href="http://niemanreports.org/articles/the-big-chill/" target="_blank">war on whistleblowers</a> , prosecutors charged Drake under the Espionage Act – a law intended to brutally punish spies – for talking to a reporter. After a four-year long ordeal that the federal judge in his case called “unconscionable,” all 10 felony charges against Drake were dropped in return for his guilty plea to a single misdemeanor.

Now, Drake said, he is throwing his weight behind H.R. 1466 <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/1466/all-info" target="_blank">H.R. 1466</a> , the Surveillance State Repeal Act.

The bill would completely repeal the 2001 PATRIOT Act (which the NSA cites as the legal basis for its bulk phone metadata collection), repeal the FISA Amendments Act (which ostensibly legitimizes Internet spying) and otherwise protect people’s privacy.“
„Chelsea Manning writes bill to protect journalism and curb Espionage Act
The US soldier imprisoned for leaking state secrets in 2010 seeks to reform laws used to prosecute journalists and whistleblowers in the name of national security+“
Most people realize that emails and other digital communications they once considered private can now become part of their permanent record.
But even as they increasingly use apps that understand what they say, most people don’t realize that the words they speak are not so private anymore, either.

Top-secret documents from the archive of former NSA contractor Edward Snowden show the National Security Agency can now automatically recognize the content within phone calls by creating rough transcripts and phonetic representations that can be easily searched and stored.

Long before the Internet I learned that anything I write (especially in business) or do could end up being used in evidence for or against me. I had security clearance for many years starting in 1963 because I was a radar designer for airplanes for over nine years. I was a prime candidate for blackmail as well. There was no way I would have betrayed my country (Canada) or my previous one (Finland). Canada did not even have its own Constitution then. Our personal freedom was guaranteed by the British North America Act.
When you thank Snowden are you doing it just on your own behalf, Germany's behalf, America's behalf, or all of humanity's behalf?

You have a total right to your own beliefs, of course now that you live in a united Germany. You did not when you lived in East Germany and marched against the government there. Now you persistently rail against the US and try to shove your beliefs down some people's throats, like mine for example. You essentially called me, a <b>Canadian<b>, a dog on G.W. Bush's leash. Some people may think I'm an SOB but have not said so to my face. You would not dare either.

FYI, I did not think that the second Iraq war was a good idea at all. Canada did not support it. One of my Arab friends said that Iraq could never become a stable democracy because it was and is composed of three peoples who don't like each other. Even Joe Biden said that once.
Now what about Russia. I might have missed it, but what are your thoughts about Russia and Ukraine?

Well, a good place to start is where you left off. So, lets talk about Russia. Or more specifically, Stalin's Russia. Or the previous example, East Germany. Ohhh, this is Canada. This is America. Abuses of power could never happen here. What the big deal about Snowden's revelations was the fact that, until his actions, NOBODY knew this was going on at all. You say, 'oh, I worked for an agency and already knew I was being watched.' But did you know to what degree and how much information was on file on you?

I presumed decades ago that <b>everything<b>on me was on file here in Canada with the RCMP, the FBI and CIA the USA, and the KGB in the USSR. I was right to be so careful, I have learned. This post is being read and recorded in real time in wikisomething as well as spy agencies.
What if you had a lot to lose? A family, kids about to enroll in college, a lifesaving medical procedure.

How could I have been affected by any of those leaks, which I had and still have? I have been married twice with a ten year gap in between, and two teenagers living with me most of the time. It's all in the public record, I'm sure.

A lot to lose. You get called in to the NSA and 'blackmailed' into co-oporating with whoever wants someone gone from the power structure. Listen more closely to what is already going on with forced confessions and people being sent to prison with false evidence.
Few of us make laws, some enforce laws, and all of us should follow the laws.
A million little ways you can be forced into subverting the basics of a democratic society.
That is an incredibly high exaggeration.
What if it gets worse? Journalists deciding not to publish important stories. I am fairly sure we are already behind the curve.

I don't think so. I am in a minority group but not visibly. I'm a white guy. What if I were a black guy and nothing else was different? I would have worked even harder, and would be a better man. That's why I admire Colin Powell.

It is only people who are brave enough to take a snowballs chance they won't be in solitary for life for nothing to show for it that the information we now know is being talked about. And yet the apathy of bored people continues. A police state is quite possible. The politicians in the U.S. are already forced to do the bidding of the most wealthy backers of campaigns and military contractors.
ISIS is forcing Canada and the US to trade off some liberty for greater protection.

You seem to be the offtopic youngster, only one thing in mind. Oh boy how old are you, 16?
Nothing more interesting in your brain reading the linked articles?

I find it hard to believe that federal courts so stubbornly refuse to require Congress to enumerate the authority that grants them the ability to pass legislation that circumvents and contradicts provisions contained within the U.S. Constitution.

The right to privacy and the security of one's property, possessions, and papers; the requirement for probable cause and obtaining a warrant to arrest someone are not things that can be legislated away by simple acts of Congress. They require a national referendum that amends the Constitution.

Instead we've got kidnapping, unjustified imprisonment, secret courts using secret evidence, assassinations, undeclared "wars," and national security agencies that ignore the laws that make it a crime to lie to federal officials and Congress. It's upside down, and few people are willing to speak out against it.

Eric Snowden was brave enough to do something about it. republicans and democrats alike refuse to support him and his cause. What is his cause? The defense of the U.S. Constitution which is the document that secures our freedom and liberty. The same document these politicians in Congress, and the politician in the White House have sworn to defend. Then we have the right wing pundits who blindly support the positions taken by the national security state and the bankers and corporations it is sworn to defend.
Best comment I have read said the next thing the will classify will be the constitution.

The sitution is really concerning and especially emptywheel.net has a lot of interesting news the msm will not report about. We need people like MrSnowden to protect our rights and maybe hold those lawbreakers in power accountable.

Most people realize that emails and other digital communications they once considered private can now become part of their permanent record.
But even as they increasingly use apps that understand what they say, most people don’t realize that the words they speak are not so private anymore, either.

Top-secret documents from the archive of former NSA contractor Edward Snowden show the National Security Agency can now automatically recognize the content within phone calls by creating rough transcripts and phonetic representations that can be easily searched and stored.

The documents show NSA analysts celebrating the development of what they called “Google for Voice” nearly a decade ago <a href=""https://firstlook.org/theintercept/document/2015/05/05/media-mining-future-now/"" target=""_blank"">nearly a decade ago</a> .
„America's Willing Helper: Intelligence Scandal Puts Merkel in Tight Place

Germany's latest spying scandal has created the biggest crisis yet for the country's foreign intelligence agency. The German government appears to have been aware of widespread US spying, possibly including economic espionage, against European targets and yet it did nothing to stop it.“
We already require, sometimes A DOZEN FBI agents to track ONE suspected terrorist. Terror suspects not unlike the ones who were shot and killed in Texas recently.

By taking many of the monitoring / surveillance tools off of the table, the cost of tracking such suspects or even initially flagging them in the first place will go up EXPONENTIALLY. The result of neutering our intelligence agencies would potentially have a HUGE proportion of suspected terrorists go undetected and untracked. We are now bound and screwed.
